content: There's still an issue in the description of the input, it says line 1: height and line 2: width but it's actually "line 1: two space-separated integers :  height and width"

Niako was right .... 

What a shame.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's a simple problem to solve and it has a good story.
Great for people to learn using a matrix/multidimensional arrays.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice, easy introduction to two-dimensional lists, if statements and probably some bools. Especially like that 0,0 wasn't always an X.
I change the stub generator input so there is no error anymore.

I will make the puzzle harder and more interesting by adding background story and making the needed run time shorter, and also give the player the input in easy way (number by number and char by char) I will give a line of numbers separate by spaces each row and a line of chars separate by spaces each row.

Hope you will enjoy the puzzle :grinning:

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: In the end, that kind of puzzle design is only about obfuscating a trivial task with nonsensical noise. The only puzzle here is to understand the unnecessarily convoluted way the input is given. That has absolutely no interest IMO.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Hopefully CG will fix the stub generator :)

Your examples might imply space padding, perhaps add a note of explanation, e.g.
(examples aligned for ease of understanding)

Change the Input specification, you have erroneously implied single integers on 2 x n x n lines.
Next [[height]] lines: Next [[width]] lines:
Should be:
Next [[height]] lines: [[width]] integers (non-zero)
Next [[height]] lines: [[width]] space separated characters ('X' or '0')

With help from the Forum I manage to fix the problems in Most of the languages but there are still few languages that have problem with the stub generator input:
F#
Go
Scala

I am working on fixing those problems.

Have a good day :relaxed:
Just to encourage you to keep going, your puzzle is cool. It can also be used for clash of code

The code stub generator throws exceptions in several languages : F#, Go, Groovy, Java, Kotlin, Objective-C, Pascal, Scala and VB.Net.

For F# it looks like a bug on CG side, the generator doesn't detect that a previously declared variable is in another inaccessible scope and should be redeclared. I haven't looked at the other ones, hopefully you can figure it out or find some help on the forum :)

Looks like a decent easy puzzle, but your description needs some english work ;)
For example :
If all the signs of the integers that their location is mark by 'X' in the second grid
in a specific order are "flipping" - the first sign is the opposite of the second sign,
the second sign is the opposite of the third sign, etc (except for the last one). output true, else output false.

Should be something like :
After taking all the integers corresponding to an X sequentially row by row, output true if those integers alternate sign at each step, otherwise output false.
I would love to hear your suggestions and opinion on the game :grinning:

Thanks a lot. I had really difficult time writing the statement because I didn't know a better way of writing this, but what you write is perfect.
I will correct this later.
Thanks. I will publish the problem in the Forum, hope somebody will help me. I also think it is not my problem but CG.
Thanks :grinning: I have wrote a post in the Forum hope somebody help me.
Thanks, I will correct this.
Thanks :relaxed:
Thanks for checking.

Thank you. :grinning:

_CG_Thibaud: We’ll look into it as soon as we can.

They said they will fix the problem, so no worry :relaxed:
Not sure I agree, we're talking about an easy puzzle with some array manipulation and some sequence analysis. Sure it's no rocket science but that's kinda the point at this difficulty level.
Thank you. I really appreciate it.
Thanks a lot :grinning:
Thanks, I changed it.
Why trivial task? I didn't see something like this in CG (Maybe I miss something but definitely this kind of task doesn't appear often).

There are lots of easy puzzles asking you to work with a grid. There are no classic puzzles asking you to detect whether an integer sequence has alternating signs, possibly because this is trivial -- for a classic puzzle -- and has no interest.

Your contribution does not link the two independent tasks, it's literally "do that thing to get the actual input, then do that other unrelated thing". Moreover there is no proper explanation/motivation/backstory for these tasks: Why is the input data initially in a grid? Why do we need to extract a sequence from it? Why do we want to detect alternating signs?

Ok, thanks. I will think about a good story to motivate and give some background about the game mission.
Working with grids is popular but this not cause for rejecting the contribution to my opinion.

> "this not cause for rejecting the contribution"
That was not a reason for rejection (I gave enough other reasons for that), that was an answer to "I didn't see something like this in CG".
Agree.. Maybe ok for a CoC... Not intriguing enuf for a puzzle.

I've taken the liberty of rewording several sentences, no change in examples/tests.
Let me know if I messed up something.
Thanks a lot. I appreciate it. You are welcome to change things just let me know.
